Conventional β zeolite exhibits limitations stemming from its constrained pore size and relatively low external surface area, impeding the efficient diffusion of bulky reactant molecules and limiting the accessibility and loading of active sites. Herein, we developed a hierarchical MnOx loaded β zeolite (MnOx/m-β) via a rational hydrothermal and subsequent redox-precipitation strategy. The hierarchical structure endows MnOx/m-β with a higher external surface area and optimized pore architecture, facilitating both the uniform dispersion of MnOx species and rapid diffusion of bulky molecules than conventional MnOx/β. Taking adsorption and catalytic oxidation of toluene, o-xylene, and 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (TMB) as probe reactions, m-β exhibits significantly enhanced adsorption capacities for o-xylene (45.3 mg/g) and TMB (91.4 mg/g), representing 1.7 and 3.8 times increases compared to conventional β, respectively. Furthermore, MnOx/m-β achieves complete oxidation of toluene, o-xylene, and TMB at ca. 260 °C, 300 °C and 250 °C, respectively, significantly lower than those required for MnOx/β. This superior catalytic performance is attributed to the synergistic effects of enhanced Mn4 + -activated lattice oxygen mobility, hierarchical mass transfer channels, and abundant accessible active sites. The designed hierarchical architecture of β holds promise for the efficient removal of bulky aromatic hydrocarbon. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hierarchical pores β zeolite Bulky VOCs Manganese oxide Catalytic oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aromatic hydrocarbons (e.g., benzene, toluene, xylene) are toxic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) with high chemical stability due to their aromatic rings, posing significant challenges for efficient removal [1,2]. Conventional noble metal catalysts, such as PtPd and Pt loaded zeolite, exhibit high activity [3,4], but suffer from high costs, susceptibility to poisoning, and limited adaptability to bulky VOCs [5–9]. Moreover, the microporous structure of traditional zeolite restricts mass transfer of bulky molecules, leading to rapid coke deposition and deactivation [10–15]. The low-cost of manganese oxides (MnOx) have emerged as promising alternatives for noble metal catalysts. Their unique [MnO6] octahedral frameworks and tunable oxygen vacancies enable efficient VOCs adsorption/activation [16–18]. For instance, hollow MnOx architectures with enriched Mn4+ and oxygen defects achieved 90 % toluene conversion at 226 °C, comparable to Pd-based catalysts [19]. Additionally, hydrophobic MnOx designs mitigated performance loss under humid conditions [20], VOCs removal efficiency of hydrophobic catalysts (Mn-Si0.06/NS) was 50 % higher than that of Mn/Al2O3 when exposed to 10 vol% water vapor, implying MnOx has great potential for industrial applications under real conditions. Hierarchical zeolite containing micro/mesopores are regarded as matching support for bulky molecules, attributed to the abundant exposed active sites and enhanced mass transfer [21]. The modifiable geometric configuration of zeolite enable superior dispersion of active components while accommodating bulky molecules [22–24]. Sun et al. [25] prepared a Pt/S-1 catalyst with a hierarchical pore structure, and the T90 of xylene oxidation reduced 20 °C compared to microporous support. Wang et al. [26] prepared mesoporous Pt/Si-WO3 catalysts, which exhibited high catalytic activity for toluene (T90= 180 °C). The increased pore size in hierarchical zeolites exposes more adsorption sites and reduces mass transfer resistance, thereby enhancing the adsorption of bulky VOCs [27,28]. Despite these advances, integrating MnOₓ with hierarchical zeolites is underexplored, primarily due to synthesis complexities in balancing pore structure and active phase dispersion. Herein, hierarchical β zeolite was first constructed via hydrothermal crystallization with the addition of mesoporous template agent, followed by controlled deposition of MnOx through a redox-precipitation strategy. This method facilitates the formation of mesoporous structure in β zeolite, thereby significantly enhancing mass transfer efficiency and accessibility of active sites. The redox-precipitation offers a rapid formation of highly dispersed MnOx nanoparticles, thus effectively preventing agglomeration and improving the activity of the catalyst. Using toluene, o-xylene, and 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (TMB) as probe reactions, we systematically evaluated the adsorption capacity and catalytic oxidation activity. It revealed that the hierarchical structure synergistically enhanced catalytic performance for bulky VOCs by facilitating reactant diffusion and providing more active sites, the underlying mechanism responsible for the improved catalytic oxidation was thoroughly discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis a. Preparation of hierarchical H-β zeolite: The material was fabricated through a hydrothermal crystallization approach, following modified protocols from prior studies [24,29]. A measured quantity of mesoporous template F127 (MW = 12,600) was mixed with 3.6 g deionized water and stirred continuously at 40 °C until fully dissolved. To this solution, 14.4 g of 25 % TEAOH aqueous solution was added stepwise, followed by the incorporation of 4.1 g high-purity fumed silica (CAB-O-SIL M5) and 0.3 g aluminum isopropoxide (≥98 % purity). The homogeneous mixture was hydrothermally treated at 155 °C for 72 h. The crystallized product was isolated by centrifugation (7500 rpm, 5 min), washed to neutral pH, dried (120 °C, 12 h), and calcined (550 °C, 8 h, 10 °C/min) to decompose organic templates. Washing the pH to neutral is to remove the residual TEAOH and unreacted silicon-aluminum species, and to maintain the crystallinity and structural stability of β zeolite. Hierarchical H-β zeolite precursor (SiAl = 46) was prepared, while conventional H-β zeolite was synthesized similarly without F127. b. Synthesis of MnO x loaded β catalysts: The MnOx-loaded catalysts were prepared by a redox-precipitation method, as reported by Wang et al. [30]. The synthesized conventional and hierarchical H-β zeolite (from step a) was added to a sufficient quantity of KMnO4 aqueous solution (with a 10 % stoichiometric excess). The solution was titrated at 80 °C with a Mn(NO3)2 precursor solution under vigorous stirring. The reaction equations are as follows： (2-1) Mn O 4 − + 3 e − + 2 H 2 O → Mn O 2 ↓ + 4 H O − (2-2) Mn 2 + + 2 H 2 O → Mn O 2 ↓ + 2 e − + 4 H + After stirring the turbid mixture at 80 °C for 2 h, the product was filtered, washed, dried (100 °C, 12 h), and calcined (400 °C, 5 h, 10 °C/min). The loading of MnOx in the synthesized catalysts was approximately 10 % (by controlling the initial concentration of precursors (e.g., KMnO4/Mn(NO3)2), the amount of manganese oxides deposited per unit mass on the surface of β zeolite was calculated according to the stoichiometric equation). The MnOx loaded conventional β zeolite catalyst was denoted as MnOx/β, and the MnOx loaded hierarchical m-β zeolite catalyst was denoted as MnOx/m-β. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Catalyst characterization details are provided in the supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic activity testing Detailed catalytic activity testing procedures can be found in the supporting information. 3 Results 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Structural properties In the XRD patterns ( Fig. 1), the characteristic peaks of conventional and hierarchical β zeolite at 2θ = 7.8° and 22.5° were observed, which can be attributed to the diffraction peaks of the BEA-type zeolite (PDF#48–0038) [31], indicating that the addition of the mesoporous template agent (F127) did not affect the crystallization of the zeolite. No characteristic peaks related to MnOx were observed in the patterns, which may indicate that MnOx exists in a low crystallinity or amorphous form. This phenomenon can be attributed to the fact that MnOx is characterized by inadequate crystallization, the dimensions of the grains are ordinarily confined to the nanometer scale, and there are concomitant phases. The characteristic peaks of MnOx in the low crystalline or amorphous forms manifest as broad and weak Bragg reflections. These are known to overlap with stronger reflections of the more crystalline phases of the β zeolite [32]. Combined with Raman and TEM results shown below, the manganese species may be α-MnO2. Besides, the diffraction of Mn-loaded β notably decreased compared to bare supports, maybe due to the coverage effects diminish diffraction intensity [33]. Fig. 2 a and b showed the N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the samples, respectively. According to the Brunauer-Deming-Deming-Teller (BDDT) classification, MnOx/β and β show typical type I isotherm characteristics, with a rapid increase in adsorption in the low-pressure region (P/P0 < 0.1) followed by a plateau in the medium- and high-pressure region tend to level off, indicating that the samples are typical microporous materials. The N2 sorption isotherms of samples m-β and MnOx/m-β did not show obvious hysteresis loops, but the continuous increase in adsorption of sample MnOx/m-β in the medium-pressure region (P/P0 = 0.5–0.9), as shown in Fig. 2 a, suggests the presence of mesopores. Additionally, the t-plot analysis of specific surface areas reveals that the external specific surface areas (Sexternal) of m-β and MnOx/m-β are both greater than 50 m2/g, with values of 85.5 and 58.7 m2/g, respectively ( Table 1), further supporting the existence of mesopores in the material. The BJH pore size distribution has a clear bulge at 3–4 nm (Fig. 2 b), which in combination with the TEM observation of internal translucent spots (Fig. 4 b and e), confirms the formation of a hierarchical structure. The absence of hysteresis loops in the mesopores may be due to the openness or high connectivity of the pores, so that the desorption paths of the open pores coincide with the adsorption paths, leading to the weakening of the hysteresis loop characteristics [34,35]. In addition, MnOx/m-β has a bulge near the pore diameter of 10 nm, which may be due to the formation of stacking pores in the mesoporous channels by MnOx. Table 1 presents the structural characteristics of the samples. Compared to β zeolite (SBET = 549.9 m2/g), the specific surface area of the m-β zeolite increased significantly (SBET = 630.2 m2/g), and the pore volume increased from 0.34 cm3/g to 0.40 cm3/g. The surface area decreased from 630.2 to 511.5 m2/g after MnOx loading, attributed to mesopore deposition and surface dispersion. Micropore confinement in β zeolite restricted MnOx deposition, maintaining the surface area of MnOx/β. Furthermore, the average pore size of β and MnOx/β was between 2 and 3 nm (Table 1), which is higher than that of conventional β zeolite (0.65 nm). This may be attributed to the formation of mesoporous structures during hydrothermal crystallization nucleation, resulting in sample pore sizes between micropores (<1 nm) and mesopores (>2 nm). 3.1.2 Morphological characterization Fig. 3 shows the FESEM images of the β, m-β, MnOx/β, and MnOx/m-β samples. According to Fig. 3 a, the crystals of β zeolite tend to aggregate from spherical to rod-like during crystallization, resulting in both spherical and rod-like morphologies. Fig. 3 b shows that the addition of F127 during crystallization suppressed the transformation of m-β zeolite crystal morphology from spherical to rod-like, leading to the absence of rod-like structures and a slight elliptical deformation of the spherical morphology. Furthermore, the m-β zeolite exhibited a loose and porous surface structure. According to Fig. 3 c and d, the sheet-like structures appearing on the outer layers of MnOx/β and MnOx/m-β samples may be MnOx. It can be observed from the appearance that the sheet-like MnOx structures are more abundant on the MnOx/m-β sample compared to MnOx/β. Table 1 indicates that the m-β zeolite, due to its higher specific surface area, allowed for high dispersion of MnOx on the support surface, which resulted in a higher MnOx loading in the MnOx/m-β catalyst compared to the MnOx/β catalyst. To better observe the microstructural characteristics of β, m-β, MnOx/β, and MnOx/m-β samples, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed. Results are shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4 a shows that the β zeolite is a solid sphere, consistent with the SEM image (Fig. 3 a). For the m-β zeolite image (Fig. 4 b), it has transparent spots in the interior, which indicates the presence of pores inside the m-β zeolite because F127 template agents were introduced during the synthesis of m-β zeolite. Due to the steric hindrance effect of the F127 macromolecular chain, the free diffusion of zeolite precursors is restricted, resulting in the accumulation and self-assembly of the primary tiny particles on the zeolite surface, and eventually forming secondary large particle aggregates (Figure S2a). When the resolution was increased to the 10 nm scale, the mesoporous channel structure could be observed more clearly (Figure S2b). TEM images of the catalysts MnOx/β and MnOx/m-β (Fig. 4 c and e) reveal that MnOx nanoparticles are predominantly encapsulated at the periphery of the supports. Detailed morphology and structure of MnOx nanoparticles on different supports were characterized by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), as shown in Fig. 4 d and f. For MnOx/β, small particles on the catalyst periphery exhibited a lattice spacing of 0.23 nm, corresponding to the α-MnO2 (301) plane. In MnOx/m-β, the periphery showed a lattice spacing of 0.38 nm, attributed to the α-MnO2 (312) plane, while the spacing within the pores was 0.28 nm, likely corresponding to the α-MnO2 (440) plane. 3.1.3 Redox and surface properties The nanometer-scale size of MnOx crystals, in conjunction with the presence of associated phases, results in the Bragg reflections of XRD being readily superimposed on the crystalline phases of the β zeolite. This phenomenon serves to impede the identification of species [32]. Consequently, Raman characterization was performed on the synthesized catalysts. The Raman spectra of the synthesized catalysts are displayed in Fig. 5. For pure β and m-β supports, no characteristic vibration peaks were observed within the detection range, effectively ruling out any interference from the supports on the positions of the characteristic peaks. As for the MnOx loaded samples, Raman bands at 320, 502, 561, and 636 cm−1 are characteristic of α-MnO2 vibrational modes. The Raman spectrum exhibits characteristic peaks associated with distinct vibrational modes: the 320 cm−1 band corresponds to the octahedral MnO6 framework vibration, while the 502 cm−1 feature is assigned to the Eg deformation mode of Mn-O-Mn linkages. Additionally, the signals at 561 and 636 cm−1 are indicative of symmetric Mn-O stretching vibrations. The spectral feature at 561 cm−1 can be assigned to the relative displacement between oxygen and manganese ions in the octahedral coordination environment, whereas the signal at 636 cm−1 is characteristic of the A1 g vibrational mode associated with Mn-O bond stretching [32]. The stretching vibration intensity at 636 cm−1 for MnOx/m-β is significantly higher than that of MnOx/β. XPS analysis further revealed that the introduction of mesopores enhanced MnOx dispersion and increased the proportion of Mn3+ on the MnOx/β surface ( Table 2). Additionally, high-temperature calcination at 550 °C suppressed the single electron configuration ( t 2 3 g e g 1 ) of Mn3+, leading to prolonged Jahn-Teller distortion and weaker Mn-O bonds [36]. For MnOx/β, calcination induced lattice distortion and amorphous defects due to its microporous structure, further weakening Mn-O bonds [37]. H2-TPR analysis was performed to examine the reducibility of MnOx/β and MnOx/m-β catalysts in Fig. 6 a. Both catalysts showed three main reduction peaks in 100–550 °C. The broad low-temperature peak (<350 °C) was deconvoluted into two components, with maxima at 248 °C (MnOx/β) and 242 °C (MnOx/m-β), assigned to the reduction of surface oxygen species [38]. The surface oxygen species on MnOx/m-β reduced at a lower temperature than those on MnOx/β, reflecting higher activity and easier reduction. The reduction peaks at 285 and 279 °C for both catalysts correspond to the transformation of MnO2 to Mn3O4, while the peak at 380 and 385 °C is assigned to the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [39]. Overall, the reduction temperatures of MnOx/m-β were lower than those of MnOx/β, indicated the high-dispersion MnOx exhibits better low-temperature reactivity [30]. Table 2 quantifies the hydrogen consumption of both samples, the result indicates that MnOx/m-β (0.16 mmol/g) exhibits a higher amount of surface oxygen species than that of MnOx/β (0.14 mmol/g), enabling it to more effectively absorb and activate oxygen molecules in the gas phase [40,41]. In order to identify and quantify the surface oxygen, O2-TPD analysis was performed (Fig. 6 b). The O2-TPD spectra can be divided into three regions: Oα and Oα' (<200 °C), Oβ and Oβ′ (200–400 °C) and Oγ (>400 °C). The Oα and Oα′ peaks corresponding to the desorption of surface adsorbed oxygen (O- and O2 -, respectively) [42]. The desorption peak temperatures of Oα and Oα′ for MnOx/m-β (118 °C/157 °C) were lower than that of MnOx/β (135 °C/180 °C). The Oβ and Oβ' peaks corresponded to the desorption of oxygen (O2 2-) from different oxygen vacancies [43], and the desorption peak temperatures of both catalysts (Oβ and Oβ') exhibited a tendency to be higher for MnOx/β (269 °C/388 °C) than for MnOx/m-β (225 °C/357 °C). The Oγ peak corresponds to the precipitation of lattice oxygen (O2−) on the surface of the catalyst [44]. As shown in Table 2 of the quantitative analysis, the amounts of [Oα] and [Oβ] were in the order of MnOx/m-β > MnOx/β, suggesting that mesoporous channels of m-β may promote the dispersion of MnOx, thus enhancing the generation of the more oxygen vacancies at the MnOx surface, in agreement with previous reports [38]. To investigate the surface elemental composition and chemical states of the MnOx/β and MnOx/m-β, XPS analysis was performed. The corresponding spectra are shown in Fig. 7, with the XPS results shown in Table 2. Following the fitting and deconvolution of the Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 spectra, the region between 660 and 635 eV was deconvoluted into two peaks (Fig. 7 a), corresponding to different Mn oxidation states. Among them, the peaks at 642.2 and 653.6 eV are attributed to Mn3+(Mn2+), and the peaks at 644.1 and 655.7 eV are attributed to Mn4+. Moreover, as illustrated in Table 2, the Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio for MnOx/β is greater than that for MnOx/m-β. indicating that there was a higher content of Mn4+ in the MnOx/m-β. The high Mn4+ concentration increases active sites on the catalyst surface, enhancing electron transfer between the catalyst and BTX, thus promoting low-temperature VOCs oxidation [45]. As illustrated in Fig. 7 b, the O1s spectra demonstrate the presence of three primary peaks within the binding energy range of 538–526 eV. The peaks at 532.5 and 535.8 eV in the high-resolution spectrum are assigned to oxygen species in Si-O bonds [46] and adsorbed water species (both chemical and physical) [47]. The 529.1 and 530.1 eV peaks are assigned to lattice oxygen (Olatt) and adsorbed oxygen (Oads), respectively [48,49]. The ratio of Oads/Olatt was found to be higher in the MnOx/m-β (1.96) than in the MnOx/β (1.43) (Table 2 ), in line with the TPR and TPD results. 3.2 Catalytic activity As demonstrated in Fig. 8 d, the adsorption capacities of β, m-β, MnOx/β, and MnOx/m-β are illustrated towards toluene, o-xylene, and TMB at room temperature. β zeolite demonstrated adsorption capacities of 44.5, 26.9, and 24.2 mg/g for toluene, o-xylene, and TMB, respectively. The observed trend aligns with the principle of zeolite matching with the pore structure, where toluene (kinetic diameter ≈ 0.60 nm) effectively accesses the microporous channels of conventional β zeolite (pore size ≈ 0.65 nm). In contrast, o-xylene (0.68 nm) and TMB (0.86 nm) experience diffusional limitations due to their bulky molecular sizes within the conventional β zeolite channels. The three-dimensional interconnected pore structure of conventional β zeolite facilitates faster diffusion for smaller molecules, resulting in a higher adsorption capacity for toluene. Breakthrough curves (Fig. 8 a) revealed that toluene had a breakthrough time of 296 min, whereas o-xylene and TMB showed significantly shorter times of 155 and 123 min (Fig. 8 b and c) , respectively. This trend highlights a notable decline in adsorption capacity with increasing molecular size for the conventional β zeolite. To improve the adsorption capacity for bulky molecules and overcome the inherent limitations of conventional β zeolite, m-β was synthesized by incorporating the mesoporous template F127. This approach led to a substantial enhancement in o-xylene and TMB adsorption capacities. Specifically, m-β demonstrated significantly higher capacities of 45.3 mg/g and 91.4 mg/g for o-xylene and TMB, respectively ( Table 3), representing an increase compared to β zeolite. These enhancements were accompanied by extended breakthrough times of 261 and 465 min, respectively (Fig. 8 b and c ). Introducing mesopores increased pore volume and diameter (Table 1), enhancing the diffusivity of bulky aromatic compounds and improving mass transport and adsorption capacity. However, toluene adsorption on m-β decreased to 15.9 mg/g (Fig. 8 d) with a breakthrough time of 106 min (Fig. 8 a), indicating a pore size mismatch between toluene and the larger mesopores of m-β. After MnOx loading, the adsorption capacities of both β and m-β based catalysts for all three VOCs were significantly reduced (Fig. 8 d). The adsorption trend for MnOx/β was toluene (25.1 mg/g) > o-xylene (11.2 mg/g) > TMB (7.8 mg/g), While MnOx/m-β followed the order of o-xylene (20.3 mg/g) > TMB (15.7 mg/g) > toluene (9.3 mg/g). The decline in adsorption capacity and shorter breakthrough times (Fig. 8 b and c ) for bulky VOCs are primarily attributed to the occupation of pore channels by MnOx species, leading to pore blockage and restricting the accessibility of bulky molecules to the internal pore structure. This phenomenon is particularly pronounced in the microporous MnOx/β, whereas in the mesoporous MnOx/m-β, although the presence of mesopores alleviates some diffusion limitations, the pore-occupying effect of MnOx still significantly impacts its adsorption performance. Fig. 9 a shows the catalytic activity for the complete oxidation of toluene over MnOx-loaded catalysts as a function of temperature. As demonstrated in Table 4, the 90 % conversion temperature (T90) for toluene was lower over MnOx/m-β (246 °C) compared to MnOx/β (253 °C). Furthermore, at 246 °C, the observed reaction rate (v) for toluene oxidation was 45.7 μmol/(g·s) for MnOx/m-β, which was considerably higher than MnOx/β (41.0 μmol/(g·s)). Fig. 9 c and e illustrate the catalytic activity for the complete oxidation of o-xylene and TMB over MnOx-loaded catalysts. The conversion trends of o-xylene and TMB on MnOx/β and MnOx/m-β were consistent with those observed for toluene, with the catalytic activity of MnOx/m-β being superior to that of MnOx/β. As demonstrated in Table 4, the T90 values for o-xylene oxidation over MnOx/β and MnOx/m-β are 293 and 281 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the reaction rate (v) is higher for the latter (38.4 μmol/(g·s)) than for the former (27.8 μmol/(g·s)). A similar trend was observed for TMB. These results strongly suggest that the higher content of surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) on MnOx/m-β catalyst plays a crucial role in enhancing the catalytic activity. The synergistic effects of MnOx, characterized by excellent low-temperature reducibility and abundant surface oxygen species, combined with the hierarchical structure and high surface area of the mesoporous support, significantly enhance the catalytic activity for the oxidation of bulky pollutants. The Arrhenius plots of toluene, o-xylene, and TMB oxidation rates are depicted in Fig. 9 b, d and f. The calculated activation energies (Ea) from these plots (Table 4) reveal that toluene oxidation had a lower Ea on MnOx/m-β (52.7 kJ/mol) compared to MnOx/β (58.9 kJ/mol). This suggests that toluene activation occurs more readily on the mesoporous support. The order of Ea for o-xylene and TMB was consistent, being lower for MnOx/m-β compared to MnOx/β. Furthermore, the differences in activation energies between MnOx/m-β and MnOx/β were more pronounced for o-xylene and TMB than for toluene. This underscores the advantage of MnOx supported on mesoporous materials for treating bulky molecular VOCs. To evaluate the stability of the MnOx/m-β and MnOx/β catalysts, continuous 50 h stability tests were conducted under condition of 500 ppm VOCs/humid air with GHSV at 60,000 h−1. As shown in Figure S2, both catalysts can maintain stable catalytic performance within 50 h. And no significant deactivation was observed. This result indicates that the hierarchical structure of m-β has good hydrothermal stability, and the MnOx/m-β catalyst has an excellent reaction lifespan, which is conducive to its practical application in real environments. 3.3 Structure-activity relationship Herein, MnOx/m-β catalyst was synthesized by hydrothermal and subsequent redox-precipitation method, the hierarchical features were verified by N2 sorption, XRD, SEM and TEM. Although no Mn species were observed from XRD, the TEM and Raman results observed the formation of MnOx and indicated the MnOx species may exist in form of α-MnO2. The hierarchical structure of m-β not only alters its adsorption properties, but also affects the chemical state of MnOx. Combined with H2-TPR, O2-TPD and XPS, it was found the mesopores play a crucial role in enabling the highly dispersed distribution of MnOx on the β zeolite. This, in turn, enhances the catalyst’s redox properties and leads to the exposure of more oxygen vacancies (OV) and active oxygen species (Oads) than those on conventional MnOx/β sample. As shown in Scheme 1, the limited pore size of conventional β zeolite restricts the diffusion of bulky VOCs into the micropores, thereby hindering the further oxidation process. By the building of hierarchical structure of m-β zeolite, the adsorption capacity for bulky VOCs was significantly enhanced. The adsorption capacities for o-xylene and TMB increased by 1.7 and 3.8 times, respectively. These results demonstrate that the mesopores play a critical role in promoting the enrichment of VOCs, which facilitates subsequent oxidation reactions. Bulky VOCs are predominantly adsorbed either physically or chemically active sites (e.g., hydroxyl groups, cations) of hierarchical β zeolite [50]. The catalytic oxidation of VOCs mainly occurs on MnOx as active sites. It was found the rate of toluene increased with the rise in desorption of [Oα] and [Oβ] (see O2-TPD). Therefore, the higher Oads concentration benefits to improve the catalytic oxidation of MnOx/m-β. Since bulky VOCs were rather stable, the oxidation process occurs with the involvement of not only the Olatt but also the electrophilic Oads (especially at a relatively low temperature). The Oads could attack the bulky organic molecule; thus, the total oxidation of bulky VOCs and the degradation of carbon skeletons can be promoted. As is known, the reducibility of metal oxides is linked to the formation of oxygen vacancies: a more readily reducible metal oxide exhibits a greater tendency to form surface defects. As the VOCs oxidation on MnOx catalysts proceeded via the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, the OV of MnOx acted as an active site as well, where bulky VOCs and oxygen can be adsorbed, activated, and then desorbed, thereby giving higher activity. Therefore, it was concluded that the catalytic activity of MnOx/m-β indeed depend on the amount of both Oads and OV (see H2-TPR and O2-TPD), and both of which were higher than those of MnOx/β. Based on above comprehension, there is a significantly synergistic effect by the introduction of mesopores and high-dispersed MnOx over MnOx/m-β catalyst. The bulky VOCs first enter the mesoporous channels and adsorb on the active sites, then combine with active oxygen species to form intermediate specie, such as benzoic alcohol, benzaldehyde and benzoic acid [8,51], these intermediate species are prone to further attacked by highly reactive oxygen species, leading to the ring cleavage and C-C bond rupture, thereby giving rise to short-chain small molecules. Finally, these short-chain molecules undergo deep oxidation processes to generate CO2 and H2O. Concurrently, under oxygen-rich conditions, gaseous O2 are preferentially adsorbed at OV, leading to the formation of active oxygen species. This process replenishes the depleted Oads and Olatt species, thus sustaining the catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusion In summary, MnOx/m-β catalyst was successfully prepared by rational hydrothermal and subsequent redox-precipitation strategy. The MnOx/m-β exhibits a significantly enhanced textural structure, characterized by an increased external surface area and optimized pore architecture compared to conventional MnOx/β zeolite. This hierarchical design facilitated both the uniform dispersion of MnOx species and the efficient mass transport of bulky VOC molecules, as evidenced by the markedly improved adsorption capacities for o-xylene and TMB. Besides, MnOx/m-β demonstrates superior catalytic performance in the complete oxidation of toluene, o-xylene, and TMB, which attributed to the synergistic combination of increased Mn4+-activated oxygen mobility, hierarchical mass transfer pathways, and accessible active sites. The catalytic activity and stability of the MnOx/m-β is comparable to some of the precious metals (such as Pd and Ru), while the feedstock cost drops significantly, highlighting the potential of industrial value for addressing complex VOCs under real conditions involving bulky molecules. coredata.dc:description: Conventional β zeolite exhibits limitations stemming from its constrained pore size and relatively low external surface area, impeding the efficient diffusion of bulky reactant molecules and limiting the accessibility and loading of active sites. Herein, we developed a hierarchical MnOx loaded β zeolite (MnOx/m-β) via a rational hydrothermal and subsequent redox-precipitation strategy. The hierarchical structure endows MnOx/m-β with a higher external surface area and optimized pore architecture, facilitating both the uniform dispersion of MnOx species and rapid diffusion of bulky molecules than conventional MnOx/β. Taking adsorption and catalytic oxidation of toluene, o-xylene, and 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (TMB) as probe reactions, m-β exhibits significantly enhanced adsorption capacities for o-xylene (45.3 mg/g) and TMB (91.4 mg/g), representing 1.7 and 3.8 times increases compared to conventional β, respectively. Furthermore, MnOx/m-β achieves complete oxidation of toluene, o-xylene, and TMB at ca. 260 °C, 300 °C and 250 °C, respectively, significantly lower than those required for MnOx/β. This superior catalytic performance is attributed to the synergistic effects of enhanced Mn4 + -activated lattice oxygen mobility, hierarchical mass transfer channels, and abundant accessible active sites. The designed hierarchical architecture of β holds promise for the efficient removal of bulky aromatic hydrocarbon.
